content: The "Silver Alert Grant Program Act of 2008" is the short title of this Act, which aims to establish purposes for the program. The Act aims to create a grant program to establish and improve State-administered notification systems for finding missing seniors with Alzheimer's and dementia-related illnesses, promote best practices for Silver Alert systems, and increase awareness for coordinated efforts. The Silver Alert Act aims to establish and improve State-administered notification systems for finding missing seniors with Alzheimer's and dementia-related illnesses, promote best practices for Silver Alert systems, and increase awareness for coordinated efforts between families, caregivers, communities, and law enforcement to locate missing individuals quickly and safely reunite them with their families. SEC. 3. FINDINGS; SENSE OF CONGRESS. According to findings by the National Institute on Aging, up to 5 million people in the US may have Alzheimer's disease, with the risk increasing with age. Data analysis shows that 1 in 8 individuals over 65 have Alzheimer's, and a new case is diagnosed every 71 seconds. Alzheimer's disease prevalence increases with age, with 1 in 8 individuals over 65 affected. The aging population, particularly the baby boomer generation, will lead to a rise in Alzheimer's cases. The Alzheimer's Association estimates that over 60% of patients will wander from their care facilities. The Alzheimer's Association estimates that over 60% of individuals with Alzheimer's disease will wander away from their care facilities. States like Colorado, Illinois, Michigan, North Carolina, and Texas have implemented notification systems to address this issue. States like Colorado, Illinois, Michigan, North Carolina, and Texas have established notification systems similar to the Amber Alert system to quickly disseminate information about missing seniors with dementia-related illnesses. This has proven to be effective in increasing the chances of locating missing individuals. States have implemented notification systems like the Amber Alert for missing seniors with dementia, increasing chances of locating them. Some states faced challenges due to budget constraints in developing such systems. Congress believes Silver Alert systems should have clear criteria for issuance. Congress believes that Silver Alert systems should have clear criteria for issuance to ensure the impact of alerts is not diminished by frequent notifications or age-based determinations. Silver Alert criteria should not be based solely on age, only for individuals unable to make personal care decisions, and initiated by someone who recently had contact with the missing individual. The Silver Alert criteria should protect the privacy and dignity of individuals, encourage training for law enforcement, and be initiated by someone who recently had contact with the missing individual. The Silver Alert criteria should protect the privacy, dignity, and autonomy of individuals, encourage training for law enforcement, and promote coordination between agencies. The Federal Government can help prevent injuries and loss of life among individuals with dementia by assisting states with the costs of implementing alert programs. The Federal Government can assist states in preventing injuries and loss of life among individuals with Alzheimer's disease and other dementia-related illnesses by helping defray the costs of establishing Silver Alert systems. The Silver Alert System Grant Program is established to help states prevent injuries and loss of life among individuals with Alzheimer's disease and other dementia-related illnesses. The Attorney General can award grants to States to establish or improve Silver Alert systems. Grants are for one-year periods and must be at least $100,000. Regulations must be established within one year. The Attorney General can award grants to States for Silver Alert systems, with a minimum grant amount of $100,000. Regulations must be established within one year for eligibility, application, and selection criteria. The Attorney General can award grants to States for Silver Alert systems, with a minimum grant amount of $100,000. Selection criteria will be used to choose the States eligible for grants, with $5,600,000 authorized for each fiscal year from 2009 to 2013. SEC. 5. ANNUAL REPORT ON SILVER ALERT SYSTEMS. The Attorney General must provide an annual report to Congress on Silver Alert systems, listing states with such systems and detailing the number of alerts issued, individuals located successfully, and the average time taken to locate them. The annual report to Congress on Silver Alert systems includes details such as the number of alerts issued, individuals located successfully, average time taken to locate them, issuing agencies, dissemination process, operational costs, criteria for issuing alerts, and extent of missing individuals. The annual report to Congress on Silver Alert systems includes details on the cost of establishing and operating the system, criteria for issuing alerts, and the extent of missing individuals crossing state lines. States have also taken actions to protect the privacy and dignity of individuals for whom Silver Alerts are issued, and improved communication between families, caregivers, law enforcement officials, and other authorities. The Attorney General determines information appropriate for the annual report on Silver Alert systems, including protecting the dignity of individuals, improving communication between families, caregivers, and authorities. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. The term "Silver Alert system" refers to a State-administered notification system to locate missing individuals with Alzheimer's disease and other dementia-related illnesses. The term "State" includes all States of the United States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Guam, the Virgin Islands, American Samoa, and the Northern Mariana Islands.
